Award.AwardTitle: Interacting Atoms in an Optical Lattice
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves a series of experiments with interacting cold atoms in far-off-resonance optical lattices. Arrays of coupled and independent one-dimensional (1D) gases of bosons will be prepared and studied to help resolve some outstanding mysteries of quantum statistical mechanics and quantum phase transitions. Prior experiments by the group have explored the physics of Bose-gases in one dimension, demonstrating that these gases never thermalize. In order to explore the crossover between one-dimensional and three-dimensional behavior, new experiments will relax the conditions that make 1D atomic gases not thermalize, and will apply new tools to measuring the onset of thermalization. In particular, a low energy 1D atom collider will be developed. These experiments will address a long open theoretical question of the existence of a threshold for chaos in a many-body quantum system, as there is in classical mechanics. This project may clarify how irreversibility of macroscopic behavior arises from the reversible behavior of individual atoms. In addition, 1D gas momentum distributions will be measured for the first time, and two-dimensional (2D) gases with variable interactions will be studied.

The broader impact of this work lies in the ability of cold-atom experiments to provide answers to long-open questions in nonlinear dynamics and mathematical physics. These experiments will train undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers in this technologically-important area of physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied a range of phenomena involving one dimensional (1D) gases of bosonic atoms. These gases are created by first using a series of techniques to cool the atoms to very low temperatures (just barely above absolute zero), and then trapping them in periodic structures formed by light, called optical lattices. 1D Bose gases are special quantum systems in that they are integrable. Being integrable implies two dramatic features: their equilbrium quantum states can be exactly calculated and they have many more conserved quantites than usual (one per atom, instead of just a few per ensemble of atoms). These extra conserved quantities means that perfect 1D gases do not thermalize-- take them out of equilibrium and they retain a memory of their initial state forever. The open question we have been most concerned with is whether when the gas is not perfectly integrable, as the real experimental system is not, the system still retains a permanent memory of its initial our of equillibrium state. The question is essentially, "what is the range of validity of statistical mechanics", which underpins our understanding of many body systems. We have made headway on answering this question, but work continues. A side result of this quest has been the study of inelastic loss in a 1D gas, which contains more physical subtlety than was previously understood. 

We have also studied other out-of-equilibrium processes with these gases, including the phenomena of "self-trapping" and "quantum distillation". In collaboration with theorists, such studies push the frontiers of our ability to understand and predict what happens in out-of-equilibrium quantum systems. Such understanding will ultimately underpin the development of new quantum based devices, including perhaps quantum computers.  The 1D gas is a particularly attractive system for such studies because the theory is often  relatively more tractable than theories in higher dimensions. To the extent that out-of-equibrium theory requires approximations, the 1D experiments allows the validity of any approximations to be tested.
